title: Forensics experts carry out bone examination on two women found dead in a freezer in east London
text:
Mihrican Mustafa, 38, also known as Mary Jane, has been identified as one of the women whose bodies were found in a freezer in a flat in east London

The cause of death for two women found in a freezer last April has still not been established nearly six months later, it emerged today.

Post-mortem reports of two women whose bodies were found in a flat freezer must be ready in three weeks, a judge has ordered.

Judge Peter Lodder QC was told expert bone examination had been completed following the grisly discovery in Newham, east London, at the end of April.

Forensic pathologist Dr Benjamin Swift is to next month submit his final report detailing the medical causes of death of missing mother-of-three Mihrican Mustafa, 38, and Hungarian national Henriett Szucs, 34.

Zahid Younis, 35, of Newham, east London, is charged with two counts of preventing a lawful burial before April 27 but today failed to appear at the hearing in Kingston Crown Court via prison video link from HMP Wandsworth.

Four friends and family of Ms Mustafa, also known as Mary Jane, who disappeared in May last year, were sat in the public gallery.

A spokesman for Scotland Yard said Ms Szucs had been in the UK for several years but was of no fixed address and had been last heard from in Summer 2016.

Police on scene outside the building in Canning Town where two bodies were found

Forensics officers leave the flat in Canning Town, east London, while investigating

Prosecutor Duncan Penny QC, updating the court on expert bone analysis of the bodies by Dr David Mangham, of Manchester University, said: 'The work is now complete however it's yet to be reduced to the form of a report.'

Judge Lodder QC said: 'I will order then that post mortem report must be available on the first of November and Dr Swift's final pathology report is available by the November 15 and the matter will be listed before me on December 17.'

A trial date has been fixed in April. A missing persons investigation was launched last year into the disappearance of Ms Mustafa, originally from Cyprus.

Mihrican Mustafa (pictured), 38, and Henriett Szucs were found dead in east London

In January, her cousin Ayse Hussain urged anyone with information to come forward.

She said: 'She's missed her own birthday, her daughter's birthday and now Christmas.

'I've been looking after her kids now and then, and I took her daughter Christmas shopping to keep her distracted. We just say mum has gone to sort herself out and say she'll be back soon. Her daughter has just started secondary school and her son is 19.'
description: Mother-of-three Mihrican Mustafa (pictured), 38, and Hungarian national Henriett Szucs, 34, were found dead in Canning Town and Zahid Younis is charged with preventing a lawful burial.
